reviews.review_msg: Content was interesting and Dr. Cooper was open to questions. However, lectures were not engaging as she just went over readings. One huge minus was that every lecture, almost one hour was dedicated to youtube videos which we can watch on our own for free - it's a waste of time and money being educated through youtube videos in university lectures.

the amount of reading required in this course is absurd, especially for a 200 level course. Also what is asked of students for exams and midterms is so much, especially in times of COVID. 3 readings a week, 2000 word midterm in 2 hours, closed book 3 hr final solely based on readings. the final required each answer to cite 2-3 readings. wild

Due to COVID, I found myself hardly ever interacting with Cooper and more with her TA, Alex. Alex was amazing, however, and through his tutorials and Cooper's lectures I felt comfortable with all assignments and concepts. She was also very easy to reach out to and understanding when I had concerns about my grades.

Elizabeth Cooper is such a joy to listen to. She's passionate, caring, and incredibly smart. She pays close attention to accessibility of students, and she does try to make the material as clear as possible. That being said, she assigns A LOT of readings. She tends to go over most of it in lecture, though. Overall a solid choice in prof!!

Great speaker who is excellent at explaining, but most of the material is boring. Heavily goes over the readings in class, so you don't need to read them. Little-to-no instructions for the research paper, but everything in the class seemed to be very easily marked. Very easy (& short) exams because she explains everything so well and then tests it.

Elizabeth is very kind. She is not very detailed in what she wants for assignments, but very accessible for help. Moreover, she includes a lot of video material, academic articles that I find strengthen my understanding of course concepts. However, lectures can get a little boring, but her lecture slides mostly explain everything.

Her Midterm and Final Exam were easy. Instructions to the papers and exam study guide were clear and you could always ask questions if you're unsure. Her TA's mainly did the marking but you were able to get the grade you expected if you were attentive and participated in the class. There was a presentation and research paper but nothing too crazy.

Home-girl assigns a lot of readings but you can easily get through it with spark-notes, just make sure to attend tutorial and review the readings prompts/lecture slides before the exams. She is an awesome prof and has a great attitude towards the students and the class! Just do the readings before lecture and merge them with your notes! :)

Even though his lecture seems dry (only from slides and textbook isn't really needed), he willing to help any student and give clear explanation. He also encouraged student to never give up. Definitely will take his class again.

He is super nice. Boring lecture but fair marker. 2 quizzes, both are open book, 1 long term paper (10pages).  Read the textbook and try to relate some concepts to the quizzes and the term paper, you can get a B.

I am a science student & took it in 2013 as an elective. Lectures are long and get boring most of the time. He dwelled more in East Asia since that's his focus and told a lot of personal stories. 2 tests - 2 or 3 out of 10 ques. - both open book. One long 10pg assignment in the end. Gotta read textbook though although his slides are good too.

bit of a boring lecturer, 3 hr classes are hard not to fall asleep in. Very nice prof, has a clear high interest in the material. both textbooks used in the course are his own, not too necessary until papers start as he covers the material well enough in lecture. Tests are open book and fair exams, have loads of time for paper, fair marking.

His textbook is a shotgun blast of world history with no attempt to bring focus on the subject itself, and he never deviates from it. No direction or criteria for tests or papers, which means expectations are low but  frustrating to work with. He doesn't seem to know how to direct learning at all. Good researcher, horrible teacher.

Although 3 hours of listening to his lectures could be boring, but he often presents very fascinating facts about everything he lectures. He is very clear and does not expect much. For both midterms, they were open book, as long as you have read the textbooks and have related the midterms to the main concepts, you are guarantee a good mark!

The most knowledgeable person in everything related to Asia, Oceania and the Americas. His hearing is poor, so two-way interaction is problematic. And lecturing is the only way he can communicate. But his narration presents a coherent and fascinating view of the world. He's also been to half the world - from Papua to Russian Far East to Peru.

Incredibly dull. Drones on an on  about Southeast Asia, which is his specialty. Reading is a lot at first, although it gets less. He pretty much follows word for word the reading, which he also wrote. Many found him tacky in terms of style (kaki pants, Hawaiian shirts, etc) and humour. Exams are open-book. Take if you like transnationalism - a lot.

A lot of reading, interesting method of teaching as he just stands there and lectures. However, by standing there and talking he makes you focus more. His testing is open-book, 3 essay questions in 2 hours for two midterms and a 10 page essay. Only take this class if it is required or you are really interested in it.
His interest in the course material seemed very low and the depth to the course was limited. The course has lots of potential but he kept it superficial. He lectures through the tutorials.
